Ruthenium based catalysts remain among the more successful complexes used in the catalysis of metathesis processes for the synthesis of new carbon-carbon bonds. The investigation of the influence of the different system moieties on its catalytic performance has led to important improvements in the field. To this extent, density functional theory (DFT) calculations have contributed significantly providing fundamental understandings to develop new catalysts. With this aim, we presented here a detailed computational study of how the nature of the anion ligand binding to the metal affects the global properties and reactivity of the catalyst. Geometric, energetic and electronic analysis have been performed to reach the key insights necessary to build structure-performance correlations. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Olefins metathesis Reaction mechanism Hoveyda-Grubbs catalysts DFT calculations Introduction Olefin metathesis is a convenient and powerful method for the formation of new carbon-carbon double bonds. It is widely exploited in a variety of fields including natural product synthesis, biochemistry, green chemistry, and polymer chemistry [1-4]. Ruthenium-based complexes, the so-called Grubbs catalysts, are highly efficient catalysts promoting the olefins metathesis process [5]. Grubbs first generation systems contain bis-phosphane ligands, Fig. 1 A, and the prototype [RuCl2(=CHPh)(PR3)2] skeleton was further modified to obtain second generation Grubbs catalyst, [RuCl2(=CHPh)(NHC)(PR3)], Fig. 1B, by exchanging one PR3 ligand with an N-heterocyclic carbene moiety, NHC [6, 7]. Since the first use of these catalysts, many efforts have been dedicated to investigate the optimal electronic features of the ligands lying on the metal. Nowadays it is widely accepted that the more active catalysts display large and strong electron-donating phosphines or NHC moieties and small electron-withdrawing anionic ligands [8, 9]. Along these attempts, Hoveyda and co-workers reported a new class of Ru-catalysts that were derived from Grubbs type complexes, by replacing the benzylidene and PCy3 moieties by a bidentate benzylidene ether ligand. This confers to the system an excellent thermal stability and oxygen and moisture-tolerance [10, 11]. In the last years, a fair number of catalyst modifications have been carried out by varying steric and/or electronic properties of the ligands in Hoveyda-Grubbs systems [12-16]. Various attempts to improve the catalytic activity, selectivity and stability were based on the replacement of the anionic chloride ligand with different electron withdrawing moieties such as bromide, iodide [8], aryloxides [17], catecholate [18], dithiolate [19] and catechothiolate ligand [20]. In 2012, Benjamin K. Keitz et al. [21] reported the synthesis of new classes of Grubbs-Hoveyda catalysts with different kinds of anionic ligands such as pivalate, carboxylate and nitrate groups and they tested them as catalysts for Z-selective olefin metathesis. Their results allowed to point out the greater activity and stability of nitrate bearing catalysts respect to carboxylate ones. Melanie S. Sanford et al. [22] reported a modification of Grubbs catalyst first generation with tertiary alkoxides as anionic ligands and demonstrated that their relatively low activity was ascribed to both the large steric bulk of the alkoxides that shields the metal from the incoming substrate, and their strong π donation ability, which inhibits olefin binding by decreasing the electrophilicity of the Ru center. Alongside with experimental works, computational studies have also contributed significantly to the understanding of the olefin metathesis reaction catalyzed by Grubbs–Hoveyda-type catalysts [23-28]. Most of the theoretical studies mainly focused on the effect of modifying the donor ligands, i.e NHC [29, 30], PCy3 [31] and the ether functionality [32]. Only few computational studies have dealt with the replacement of the chlorine ligands with different groups in the catalyst structure [18, 33, 34]. For a further contribution, the objective of this study is to explore the impact of altering the anionic ligands on the property and reactivity of Grubbs-Hoveyda catalyst during the metathesis reaction process. With this aim in mind, we present here a density functional theory (DFT) study of the energy scenarios together with orbitals and chemical reactivity descriptors analysis to gain a deeper understanding of the elements affecting the catalyst varying the anionic ligands lying on the metal. Computational methods All the molecular geometries were optimized at the DFT level of theory [35, 36] using the B3LYP hybrid functional [37, 38] with the Gaussian 09 suite of programs [39]. For Ru, the basis set LanL2DZ was used, while for the other atoms, i.e. H, C, S, N, O, Cl and F, the 6-311G+(d,p) basis sets was selected. Vibrational analysis was performed for all stationary points to characterize them as transition states (TSs) or equilibrium structures. Single-point energy calculations were performed on these geometries using B3LYP/TZVP-LANL2DZ (Ru) with the PCM solvation model for di-chloromethane [40]. Thermal energies and entropy effects are calculated at 298 K and 1 atm, with no further entropic corrections [41]. The theoretical method used above is found to be satisfactory in previous studies on related ruthenium catalysts [27, 42, 43]. Molecular electrostatic potential intramolecular charge transfer (ICT) have been determined at DFT/B3LYP level using NBO (Natural Bond Orbital) calculations [44] as implemented in Gaussian 09 package [36]. Chemical reactivity indexes have been calculated using the standard working equations as follows. The chemical potential ( μ ) is determined as the derivative of the energy respect to the number of electrons [41], μ = ( ∂ E ∂ N ) ν while the chemical hardness ( η ) is determined as the second derivative of the energy with respect to the number of electrons [45, 46], η = ( ∂ 2 E ∂ N 2 ) ν = ( ∂ μ ∂ N ) ν In numerical forms, μ and η are calculated with the approximations of Koopmans’ theorem [47]: μ ≅ 1 2 ( ε L + ε H ) η ≅ 1 2 ( ε L − ε H ) where Η and L are used to indicate the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO), respectively [37, 45]. Finally, the electrophilicity (ω) is defined as the affinity of a molecule to interact with a nucleophile and determined as in the equation below [37, 48, 49], ω = μ 2 2 η Results and discussion Geometry analysis. The systems selected for this study are reported in Fig. 2 . All the complexes considered display the NHC with a saturate backbone, a phenyl ring on the nitrogen atoms, and the ether moiety bearing an ethyl substituent. The chosen anionic ligands cover a wide range on the electrodonicity scale, and they are quite small in order to avoid any shielding caused by using bulkier ligands. As representative structures, we considered the precatalyst geometry and the metallacyclobutanes deriving from metathesis of C1-C8 with ethylene. Table 1 reports selected computed values for bonds length, angles and dihedrals for the pre-catalyst optimized structures. The computed geometry for C1 is in agreement with the X-ray data published for a related system [11], and with the geometries obtained in previous theoretical studies [50, 51], making us confident of the chosen computational protocol. As suggested by Nuñez-Zarur et al. [25], the key structural parameters governing the reactivity of Fisher type of Ru-metathesis catalysts are the strength of the Ru-O interaction, the metal–carbene bond (Ru-C2), and the bond between the metal carbene and the phenyl ring of the Hoveyda ligand (C2-C3), with the guideline that larger C2-C3 bond length means lower π character of the C-C bond. In the current study, the C2-C3 bond does not seem to be meaningfully affected by the change in the anionic ligand; in fact, the length of this bond is mostly identical for all the studied catalysts (see Table 1). On the other side, the Ru-O bond distance scales between 2.27 and 2.30 Å, except for C6 (with OCH3 as anionic ligand), which shows a longer Ru-O distance of 2.32 Å. This suggests a lower overlap between the O lone pair and the empty orbital on Ru, which should facilitate the initiation step (i.e. dissociation of the ether ligand from Ru to coordinate the olefin) [24]. The Ru-C2-C3-C4 dihedral is almost planar for all systems ranging between 0.4o and 3.5o. Next we move to the metallacyclobutanes (see Fig. 3 ), the key intermediate along the catalytic cycle, whose opening towards products or back to reactants can determine the outcome of the reaction. This intermediate has a trigonal bipyramid structure (TBP), with the two anionic ligands being in the axial plane. As reported in the literature for Ru based catalysts, the ruthenacyclobutane is flat and presents a considerably long Ru•••C2 distance [52, 53]. For the studied systems, this distance varies in the range of 2.01-2.08 Å with M5 (with OH as anionic ligand) showing the shortest value and M3 (with CF3 as anionic ligand) the longest one (see Table 2 ). Regarding the distance between the metal and the middle carbon (Ru-Cb), it is ranged between 2.31 Å for M6 (with OCH3 as anionic ligand) and 2.29 Å for M5 (with OH as anionic ligand). As reported by Suresh and Koga in 2004 [54], the Ru-Cb distance may give an indication of the overlap between the Ca-Cb-C2 bonding orbital and the empty dy2 orbital on the metal, with a short Ru-Cb bond aligning with an elongated and more easily cleavable Ca-Cb bond. Accordingly, in this study, M6 displays the longer Ru-Cb distance and the shorter Ca-Cb bond, which may impede the cleavage of the Ca-Cb bond decreasing the rate of the following steps. Energy analysis To understand the effect of the anionic ligands on the reactivity of the system, we have performed mechanistic energy calculations. The catalytic cycle proposed by Chauvin in 1971 begins with the initiation step in which the active species is formed by the reaction between the olefin substrate and the metal alkylidene pre-catalyst [55]. In case of Grubbs-Hoveyda catalysts, the activation process includes a gradual decreasing of the Ru–O interaction to form a vacant Ru binding site for the incoming olefin substrate [26-28, 51] (see Scheme 1). Numerous studies have dealt with the investigation of the whole catalytic cycle including initiation and propagation mechanisms [56-61]. Here we focus on the first step of the reaction calculating the energy required during the initiation pathway while changing the anionic ligands in the catalyst structure. Discussion of the energy profile is based on free energies (ΔG) relative to the pre-catalyst and ethylene substrate considered at infinite distance (zero point energy). Many studies reported in the literature questioned on the features of the initiation mechanism more likely to happen in the experimental conditions. For example, Ashworth et al. hypothesized that the interchange mechanism would be more favorable than the associative and the dissociative pathways for the reaction of ethylene and ethyl vinyl ether in presence of Hoveyda-Grubbs catalyst [51]. Thiel et al. investigated the mechanism of the initiation reaction of electronically and sterically modified Grubbs−Hoveyda-type complexes for olefins substrates with different steric hindrance [58]. The study showed that the initiation step can follow two parallel pathways: a dissociative mechanism and an interchange mechanism. Importantly, it was concluded that the selection of one of the two possible modes of activation is highly dependent on the steric and electronic properties of the ruthenium complex, with the less sterically hindered olefins preferring the interchange mechanism. This study proved also that the acceleration of the interchange or the dissociative mechanism could be achieved by adding electron-withdrawing groups at the benzylidene ether moiety of the Grubbs−Hoveyda complexes [58]. A comprehensive theoretical investigation of the three possible mechanisms (associative, dissociative and interchange) for the activation of the Grubbs−Hoveyda precatalysts using DFT calculations have been reported by F. Nuñez-Zarur et al [25, 52, 62, 63]. The findings showed that the dissociative and the interchange mechanism could be considered as dominant pathways, with the associative mechanism being always disfavored with high-energy barriers. For this reason, we focused here only on the stepwise dissociative mechanism and on the concerted interchange mechanism for the initial breaking of the Ru-O bond and coordination of ethylene to the metal (formation of A) for the eight catalysts considered. The interchange mechanism requires the overcome of transition state TS1 consisting in the breaking of the Ru-O bond and the simultaneous approaching of the olefin to form A. Instead, the dissociative mechanism consists in the initial rotation around the C2-C3 bond, leading to the lengthening of the Ru–O bond (TS1D) and formation of the 14 electron species D, having a vacant site on Ru. Next, the olefin approaches to Ru through transition state TS2D leading to the formation of A. From A, the common pathway to both mechanisms consists in the formation of the metallacycle B (cycloaddition) and in its following re-opening (cycloreversion) leading to the formation of the new Ru-methylidene bond in C. The release of the oxygenated fragment generates the active species ready to enter in the general catalytic cycle. Since several studies have depicted these pathways for chloride containing Hoveyda-Grubbs analogues [52, 63], we use here the energy profile of C1 as a reference for the other catalytic systems, see Fig. 4 . Regarding the dissociative mechanism, the initial alkoxy dissociation requires an energy barrier of 14.3 kcal/mol, with intermediate D lying almost 5 kcal/mol above the starting reactants. After the vacant site has been created, the alkene coordination step takes place through transition state TS2D, which overall requires overcoming a barrier of approximately 20 kcal/mol and it is isoenergetic with the following A complex. For the interchange mechanism, the activation process requires overcoming an energy barrier of 28.3 kcal/mol, almost 9 kcal/mol higher than the rate determining transition state for the dissociative pathway (TS2D). From A the two mechanisms follow the same pathway, with the opening of the metallacycle B through transition state TS3 (at 28.7 kcal/mol) representing the higher energy barrier to form C. We have calculated the energies for all the systems considered here, see Table 3 . The numbers reported in Table 3 indicate that the dissociative path is always kinetically favored over the concerted interchange pathway, with C3 and C6 having the highest energies for TS1, possibly due to the greater steric hindrance of the CF3 and OCH3 groups which disfavor the more congested interchange pathway. Focusing on the dissociative mechanism, the results show two trends. First, TS1D requires less energy for C5, C6 and C7 (12.2, 13.0 and 13.1 kcal/mol), which exhibit more electron donating ligands (i.e. OH, SH and OCH3) that are able to increase the electronic density on the metal center, favoring the breaking of the Ru-O bond. Higher energy is required for complexes C3 and C8 (19.9 and 16.9 kcal/mol), due to the high electron withdrawing character of CF3 and CN ligands. On the other hand, the approach of ethylene to the Ru center in TS2D requires less energy in the case of C1, C2 and C8, in agreement with the presence of more withdrawing ligands (Cl, COOH, and CN) that deplete electrons from the metal favoring the coordination of the incoming ethylene. Moving to the second part of the activation pathway, starting from intermediate A, the energy barrier required to form the metallacycle intermediate B (TS2) varies in a range between 24 and 37 kcal/mol, while metallacyclobutane opening barrier (TS3) covers the 26-41 kcal/mol range, with TS3 being highest than TS2 for all the systems considered (except for C2 and C3, having TS3 almost isoenergetic with TS2). These results show how the presence of different withdrawing/donor groups influence the Ru electronic structure and, consequently, the strength of the Ru-O/Ru-C interactions and the corresponding energy scenario. However, as expected, also the steric hindrance of the ligand affects the pathways and, as consequence, the final energy trends will depend on a balance between both these ligand features. Electronic analysis Rationalizing the reactivity of systems is crucial for the development of the more appropriate reaction approach. To this extent, DFT methodologies provide useful insights since they have access to properties of the species at molecular level, an information that can complement experimentally derived knowledge [45]. In this section, we will focus on the orbital analysis based on HOMO and LUMO, and on the chemical reactivity index ω, explained in the methods section. In the pre-catalyst, the HOMO is localized on the Ru-X and Ru-NHC σ-bonds while the LUMO is mainly localized on the benzylidene moiety π* orbital [24]. Replacing the two chloride ligands of C1 by the other anionic ligands affects the frontier molecular orbitals, see Table 4 . Both the HOMO and the LUMO orbitals are stabilized in C3 (with CF3 as anionic ligand), C4 (with Cl and COOH as anionic ligands) and C8 (with CN as anionic ligand), as similarly reported in previous studies [64, 65] showing that the presence of a more electron withdrawing substituent on the metal leads to a general decrease in the frontier orbital energies of the starting complex. At the contrary, for C5 (with OH as anionic ligand), C6 (with OCH3 as anionic ligand) and C7 (with SH as anionic ligand) both HOMO and LUMO energies are increased respect to C1. These variations in the HOMO and LUMO energies results in a HOMO-LUMO gap, ΔEL-H, ranging from 2.92 eV in C7 to 3.67 eV in C3. In the case of the metallacyclobutane intermediate, the HOMO is basically localized on the dxy or dyz orbital of the Ru atom, and the LUMO on the π∗ orbital of ethylene. The energy trend for these orbitals follows the one already explained for the starting complex, with systems bearing electron withdrawing ligands, such as C3, C4 and C8, having clearly more stable frontier orbitals, see Table 4. Also at the metallacycle level the smaller and larger HOMO-LUMO gaps correspond to the complexes with SH and CF3, which are M7 and M3, with ΔEH-L of 2.48 and 3.47 eV, respectively. Finally, the electrophilicity index calculated on the pre-catalysts and metallacycles in the gas phase, also reported in Table 4, indicate that the presence of more electron withdrawing ligands on the metal can be exploited to enhance the global electrophilicity of the system, reflecting a higher propensity to react with the incoming olefin, with CF3 and CN ligands having the greatest effect. Structure-performance correlation The typical approach of the so called “rational” catalyst design, is to use molecular descriptors, able to capture the experimental behaviours of the catalysts, to develop structure-performance relationships that can be used for guiding catalysts engineering. With this approach in the mind, we explored if electronic features of precatalysts C1-C8 could capture the expected behaviour in catalysis. As measure of the expected catalytic performance we used the energy of the rate determining transition state TS3 relative to reactants. As molecular descriptors we will focus on the electronic properties discussed in the sections above. All the plots for C1-C8 are reported in Fig. 5 , those of M1-M8 are reported in the Supporting Information. Nevertheless the general trend discussed in the previous section, HOMO energies do not seem capable to capture the expected catalyst behaviors, with a correlation coefficient R2 of only 0.56. Even worse is the correlation between TS3 energy and the HOMO-LUMO energy gap, with a R2 of 0.02. Conversely, LUMO energy correlates very well with the TS3 energy, with a R2 value of 0.84. It seems evident that the presence of more electron withdrawing groups like those in C8, C1, C2, C3 and C4 stabilizes the LUMO orbitals decreasing meaningfully the energy required for TS3 and, thus, increasing the reactivity of the catalyst. This aspect seems to be very relevant, since moving from C8, with the most stable LUMO, to C5, corresponding to the less stable LUMO, TS3 energy varies by more than 10 kcal/mol. Similar results are achieved performing the analysis on metallacycles M1-M8. Considering the identity of the LUMOs, i.e. π* orbital of the benzylidene moiety and π∗ orbital of ethylene for the precatalysts and metallacycles, respectively, having them more energetically accessible means to facilitate the formation of the π-bond CHR=CH2 and Ru=CH2 in TS3. Similar reasoning can be applied to the electrophilicity index, which also correlates with the TS3 energy with a R2 value of 0.84. As discussed above, electrophilicity increases in presence of more electron withdrawing ligands, which causes a decrease in the energy of TS3. As some of the electronic features considered above can catch properties of the systems quantitatively, we decided to check if a simple empirical parameter, capable to capture the electronic influence of a group, could correlate similarly well with the TS3 energies. As the most obvious choice, we focused on the Hammet constant σp, as it is a descriptor largely used to treat the electronic effect of substituents on rates and equilibria in various kinds of chemical reactions [66]. The linear correlation reported in Fig. 6 , with a R2 value of 0.89, is even slightly better than the correlations achieved using the LUMO energy or the electrophilicity index, see Fig. 5, and it can be considered a sort of validation of the DFT calculations performed in this work. Of course, the possibility of using a tabled descriptor, such as the Hammet parameter, should allow engineering catalysts without having to perform electronic structure calculations. Conclusions Many efforts have been dedicated to study the metathesis of olefin substrates catalyzed by ruthenium complexes both with experimental and computational techniques. After the general mechanism leading to the formation of the new carbon-carbon bonds has been established in the early 70s, many studies have focused on refining the catalyst features in order to improve the reaction yield, selectivity etc. The role of the different ligands lying on the metal has been analyzed during the years to depict the ideal ruthenium environmental able to maximize the performance of the system. It is now widely accepted that the more active catalysts display large and electron-donating sigma donor ligands, as phosphines or NHC moieties, and small electron-withdrawing anionic ligands, as chlorine. Among the others, the modification of the metal coordination sphere by adding bidentate benzylidene ether ligands in the Grubbs-Hoveyda catalysts conferred to the systems an excellent thermal stability and oxygen and moisture-tolerance. In this study we focused on this kind of catalysts changing the anionic ligand lying (X) on Ru and studying the effect on the geometric and electronic properties of the whole system. Eight different systems have been considered with X properties covering a wide range of electrodonicity. Orbital analysis and reactivity index calculations allowed us to rationalize the change in the electronic state of the catalyst and detailed energy calculations of the initiation pathways indicated how the reactivity of the system undergo the change caused by X. Altogether, we built in the end of the work structure-performance correlations between the energy of the rate determining state along the studied pathways, i.e. the opening of the metallacyle intermediate, and the Hammet constant of the anionic ligand as measure of its electronic properties. The insights reached here could be usefully exploited to predict the behavior of catalysts bearing different anions and to rationally design better performing systems. coredata.dc:description: Ruthenium based catalysts remain among the more successful complexes used in the catalysis of metathesis processes for the synthesis of new carbon-carbon bonds. The investigation of the influence of the different system moieties on its catalytic performance has led to important improvements in the field. To this extent, density functional theory (DFT) calculations have contributed significantly providing fundamental understandings to develop new catalysts. With this aim, we presented here a detailed computational study of how the nature of the anion ligand binding to the metal affects the global properties and reactivity of the catalyst. Geometric, energetic and electronic analysis have been performed to reach the key insights necessary to build structure-performance correlations.
coredata.dc:title: Influence of the anionic ligands on properties and reactivity of Hoveyda-Grubbs catalysts
